dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That floating boom system from Ocean Cleanup just deployed from Los Angeles Bay this Tuesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That floating boom system from Ocean Cleanup just deployed from Los Angeles Bay this Tuesday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh right, the one designed by that Dutch inventor, Boyan Slat. He was only 21 when he started the whole thing back in 2015, wasn't he?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh right, the one designed by that Dutch inventor, Boyan Slat. He was only twenty one when he started the whole thing back in twenty fifteen, wasn't he?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and their goal is honestly massive—they're to clean up a quarter of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in just ten years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and their goal is honestly massive-they're to clean up a quarter of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in just ten years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, with the help of dozens of more booms, is estimated to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within the first five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, what, like 2.6 million square kilometers? It's just mind-boggling how much debris is out there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, what, like two point six million square kilometers? It's just mind-boggling how much debris is out there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers and 1.8 trillion pieces of debris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And each boom can trap up to 75,000 pounds of plastic per year as it drifts between California and Hawaii.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And each boom can trap up to seventy five thousand pounds of plastic per year as it drifts between California and Hawaii.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each boom will trap up to 150,000 pounds of plastic per year as they float along the currents between California and Hawaii.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But I'm curious about the netting—it's only five feet deep, so theoretically fish should be able to swim under it, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But I'm curious about the netting-it's only five feet deep, so theoretically fish should be able to swim under it, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the boom floats, it collects trash in the U shaped system, which has 10 feet of netting below it to collect smaller fragments of plastic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's the idea, but like you said, it's still unproven in open water. We won't really know till they start hauling in plastic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the idea, but like you said, it's still unproven in open water. We won't really know till they start hauling in plastic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're planning to tow it out around early November, after testing wraps up. I hope the tech holds up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're planning to tow it out around early November, after testing wraps up. I hope the tech holds up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, after undergoing testing, will be towed out 1,400 miles to the garbage patch around mid-October and begin collecting trash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Me too. Though I did read that another group, Oceanic Solutions, is working on something similar—backed by Elon Musk and Bill Gates, no less.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me too. Though I did read that another group, Oceanic Solutions, is working on something similar-backed by Elon Musk and Bill Gates, no less.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Heavy hitters for sure. But Ocean Cleanup seems further along with actual deployment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Heavy hitters for sure. But Ocean Cleanup seems further along with actual deployment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No other company has a deployable system able to clean up the garbage patch on this scale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And if they can actually recycle all that plastic… that'd be a game-changer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And if they can actually recycle all that plastic... that'd be a game-changer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once the boom is full, a vessel will meet the boom to collect the plastic and transport it to land for sorting and recycling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For real. Alice Chen, that biologist from Marine Trends, she's been covering this closely for the Journal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For real. Alice Chen, that biologist from Marine Trends, she's been covering this closely for the Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, she's got that Pacific Ocean expertise from her PhD work. Always brings a solid perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, she's got that Pacific Ocean expertise from her PhD work. Always brings a solid perspective.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Fingers crossed this system works without harming marine life. We need solutions, not more problems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Fingers crossed this system works without harming marine life. We need solutions, not more problems.

artist_script:
HostA: That floating boom system from Ocean Cleanup just deployed from Los Angeles Bay this Tuesday.
HostB: Oh right, the one designed by that Dutch inventor, Boyan Slat. He was only 21 when he started the whole thing back in 2015, wasn’t he?
HostA: Yeah, and their goal is honestly massive—they’re to clean up a quarter of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in just ten years.
HostB: Which is, what, like 2.6 million square kilometers? It’s just mind-boggling how much debris is out there.
HostA: And each boom can trap up to 75,000 pounds of plastic per year as it drifts between California and Hawaii. The scale is wild.
HostB: But I’m curious about the netting—it’s only five feet deep, so theoretically fish should be able to swim under it, right?
HostA: That’s the idea, but like you said, it’s still unproven in open water. We won’t really know till they start hauling in plastic.
HostB: And they’re planning to tow it out around early November, after testing wraps up. I hope the tech holds up.
HostA: Me too. Though I did read that another group, Oceanic Solutions, is working on something similar—backed by Elon Musk and Bill Gates, no less.
HostB: Heavy hitters for sure. But Ocean Cleanup seems further along with actual deployment.
HostA: Absolutely. And if they can actually recycle all that plastic… that’d be a game-changer.
HostB: For real. Alice Chen, that biologist from Marine Trends, she’s been covering this closely for the Journal.
HostA: Right, she’s got that Pacific Ocean expertise from her PhD work. Always brings a solid perspective.
HostB: Definitely. Fingers crossed this system works without harming marine life. We need solutions, not more problems.
